Message.Title: Yahoo's minders didn't like last night's discussion about the wealthiest 400 Americans
Message.Msg: owning as much as the bottom 150 million, so I feel compelled to restart that conversation. It began with the usual whining from one not-so-thoughtful conservative about his objection to any new taxes, and accusations that anyone who wants to increase taxes on the rich is bent on destroying jobs and the economy. I opined that defenders of trickle-down, no-taxes economics were either unable to recognize the ultra-rich as a tax on everyone else, or were simply behaving like ostriches. To reiterate: Anyone whose thinks that the hidden burden of carrying a giga-rich ruling class is not a tax should look to the citizens of France for a few trenchant history lessons to the contrary that might better illuminate their dim view [and grasp] of the issue. The difference is that even the illiterate rabble who carried out the French Revolution were able to recognize the royals and their cohorts as an unjust tax, whereas many of the contributors to this board seem unable or unwilling to do the same. This country has become so enamored of the chiseler, the con man, and the card sharp, we've granted them the status of kings and queens of the realm. They hold all the aces; nothing below a jack plays, and the best the rest of us jokers can hope for is to be included now and then in one of their Charity Night penny-ante games. All that remains is for the next round of fiat currency to bear a Mississippi steamboat on one side, the grinning visage of good-looking Bret Maverick on the other, and the motto "Shut up and deal!" The conservatives on this board seem quite enamored of Bret's style, and eager to emulate it here: make a flashy and noisy entry into the game; flash a few bills and slip a few cards into the deck, play a hand or two, and then move on to the next table hoping no one notices their slight-of-hand maneuver. Come back, you Baltic Smugglers; let's play a few hands! ROTFLMAO at people whining about the wrong taxes everywhere.

Message.Msg: I just googled them and their Hornet Max gas-powered version rings all of my bells. 120 mile range, 40 mph top speed, 10,000 ft. ceiling.....they're too shy to list the payload capability, but with those numbers and an empty but fueled take-off weight of around 25 pounds, I'd estimate a useful payload over shorter distances and low altitude in the neighborhood of 3-5 pounds. Low speed means the drag from additional stealth paneling and materials won't have too much effect on overall performance or payload, and another pound or two of payload capability could be gained by shedding the skids and other non-essentials if landings aren't a concern. ROTFLMAO at new do-it-yourself options arriving every day.
